topics.title: Skull
topics.description: Study of the cranial and facial bones.
topics.notes:
### ü¶¥ Skull Overview

The human skull consists of **22 bones**, which are divided into:

- **8 Cranial Bones**
- **14 Facial Bones**

It forms the skeleton of the head and protects the brain while supporting facial structures.

---

### üß† Cranial Bones (8)

These bones enclose and protect the brain:

1. **Frontal**
2. **Parietal** (2)
3. **Temporal** (2)
4. **Occipital**
5. **Sphenoid**
6. **Ethmoid**

> üß© The frontal bone forms the forehead and the roof of the orbits.

---

### üòä Facial Bones (14)

These shape the face and support sensory organs:

- **Maxilla** (2)
- **Zygomatic (cheekbones)** (2)
- **Nasal** (2)
- **Lacrimal** (2)
- **Palatine** (2)
- **Inferior nasal conchae** (2)
- **Mandible** (1 ‚Äî only movable skull bone)
- **Vomer** (1)

---

### üï≥Ô∏è Important Foramina

Openings in the skull through which nerves and vessels pass:

| Foramen           | Transmits                            |
|------------------|--------------------------------------|
| Foramen magnum   | Spinal cord, vertebral arteries      |
| Optic canal      | Optic nerve (CN II)                  |
| Jugular foramen  | CN IX, X, XI, jugular vein           |
| Foramen ovale    | Mandibular branch of CN V (V3)       |

---

### üìå Clinical Relevance

- **Fractures** of the skull can be life-threatening if cranial nerves or vessels are damaged.
- The **pterion** is a thin region vulnerable to **epidural hematoma** if the middle meningeal artery is ruptured.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

The skull is not a single bone but a complex structure of **22 bones** that together provide **protection**, **support**, and **access** for vital neurovascular structures.

topics.title: Vertebral Column
topics.description: Anatomy and function of the human spine.
topics.notes:
### ü¶¥ Vertebral Column (Spine) Overview

The vertebral column is the **central support structure** of the body, made up of **33 vertebrae**:

- 7 Cervical
- 12 Thoracic
- 5 Lumbar
- 5 Sacral (fused)
- 4 Coccygeal (fused)

---

### üß© Functions

- **Supports** the skull and trunk
- **Protects** the spinal cord
- Allows **flexibility** and **movement**
- Acts as an **attachment point** for ribs and muscles

---

### üß† Regions of the Spine

| Region     | Vertebrae Count | Key Features                    |
|------------|------------------|----------------------------------|
| Cervical   | 7                | Small, bifid spinous processes   |
| Thoracic   | 12               | Articulates with ribs            |
| Lumbar     | 5                | Large bodies, weight-bearing     |
| Sacral     | 5 (fused)        | Forms posterior pelvis (sacrum) |
| Coccygeal  | 4 (fused)        | Vestigial tailbone (coccyx)      |

---

### üîé Vertebra Structure

Each typical vertebra has:

- **Body**
- **Vertebral foramen**
- **Spinous process**
- **Transverse processes**
- **Articular facets**

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **Herniated Disc**: Displacement of intervertebral disc can compress spinal nerves (common in lumbar).
- **Scoliosis**: Lateral curvature of the spine.
- **Kyphosis**: Excessive posterior curvature (hunchback).
- **Lordosis**: Exaggerated lumbar curve.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

The spine is a flexible but strong column of **33 vertebrae** that provides **support, protection, and motion**, while housing the **spinal cord**.

topics.title: Anatomical Terminology

topics.notes:
### üß≠ Anatomical Terminology & Orientation

Anatomical terminology is essential for accurately describing **locations**, **positions**, and **relationships** of body structures.

---

### üìê Anatomical Position

The **standard reference position** for the human body:

- Standing upright
- Facing forward
- Arms at the side
- Palms facing forward
- Feet slightly apart

---

### üß≠ Anatomical Planes

|-----------------|--------------------------------------------|

| **Coronal**     | Divides the body into front & back         |

|---------------|------------------------------------|

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

Learning standard anatomical terms helps ensure **clear communication** among healthcare professionals when describing parts of the body or performing procedures.

topics.title: Thoracic Wall & Ribs
topics.description: Structure and function of the thoracic wall and rib cage.
topics.notes:
### üõ°Ô∏è Thoracic Wall & Ribs

The thoracic wall consists of the rib cage, muscles, and fascia that protect the thoracic organs.

---

### ü¶¥ Rib Cage Structure

- **12 pairs of ribs**:
  - Ribs 1-7: True ribs (attach directly to the sternum)
  - Ribs 8-10: False ribs (attach indirectly via costal cartilage)

---

### üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Muscles of the Thoracic Wall

- **Intercostal muscles**: External, internal, and innermost intercostals aid in respiration.
- **Diaphragm**: Primary muscle of respiration separating thoracic and abdominal cavities.

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **Rib Fractures**: Commonly occur due to trauma; may lead to pneumothorax.
- **Thoracic Outlet Syndrome**: Compression of neurovascular structures between the clavicle and first rib.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

The thoracic wall and rib cage provide structural support, protect vital organs, and play a crucial role in respiration.

topics.title: Lungs & Pleura

topics.notes:
### üå¨Ô∏è Lungs & Pleura

The lungs are the primary organs of respiration, housed within the pleural cavities.

---

### ü´Å Lung Anatomy

- **Right Lung**: Three lobes (superior, middle, inferior) separated by horizontal and oblique fissures.
- **Left Lung**: Two lobes (superior, inferior) separated by an oblique fissure; includes the cardiac notch.

---

### ü©π Pleura

- **Visceral Pleura**: Covers the lungs.
- **Parietal Pleura**: Lines the thoracic cavity.
- **Pleural Cavity**: Potential space between the two layers containing lubricating fluid.

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **Pneumothorax**: Air in the pleural cavity causing lung collapse.
- **Pleural Effusion**: Excess fluid in the pleural cavity.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

Understanding the structure of the lungs and pleura is essential for diagnosing and treating respiratory conditions.

topics.title: Heart & Pericardium
topics.description: Detailed anatomy of the heart and its surrounding pericardial sac.
topics.notes:
### ‚ù§Ô∏è Heart & Pericardium

The heart is a muscular organ responsible for pumping blood, enclosed within the pericardium.

---

### ü´Ä Heart Structure

- **Chambers**: Right atrium, right ventricle, left atrium, left ventricle.
- **Valves**: Tricuspid, pulmonary, mitral (bicuspid), aortic.

---

### ü©π Pericardium

- **Fibrous Pericardium**: Outer tough connective tissue layer.
- **Serous Pericardium**: Inner double-layer with parietal and visceral layers; pericardial cavity contains lubricating fluid.

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **Pericarditis**: Inflammation of the pericardium.
- **Cardiac Tamponade**: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial cavity restricting heart function.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

A thorough understanding of the heart and pericardium is vital for recognizing and managing cardiovascular diseases.

topics.title: Abdominal Wall

topics.notes:
### üèãÔ∏è Abdominal Wall

The abdominal wall encloses the abdominal cavity and consists of multiple layers.

---

### üß± Layers (Superficial to Deep)

1. Skin

---

- **Internal Oblique**: Same as external oblique.
- **Transversus Abdominis**: Compresses abdominal contents.
- **Rectus Abdominis**: Flexes vertebral column, compresses abdomen.

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **Hernias**: Protrusion of abdominal contents through the wall; common types include inguinal and umbilical hernias.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

The abdominal wall's structure is crucial for protecting internal organs and maintaining intra-abdominal pressure.

topics.title: Gastrointestinal Tract
topics.description: Comprehensive overview of the human gastrointestinal system.
topics.notes:
### üçΩÔ∏è Gastrointestinal Tract

The gastrointestinal (GI) tract is a continuous tube extending from the mouth to the anus, facilitating digestion and absorption.

---

### üõ§Ô∏è Major Components

1. **Mouth**: Mechanical digestion begins; saliva initiates chemical digestion.
2. **Esophagus**: Transports food to the stomach.
3. **Stomach**: Secretes acid and enzymes; churns food into chyme.
4. **Small Intestine**: Duodenum, jejunum, ileum; primary site for nutrient absorption.
5. **Large Intestine**: Absorbs water; forms and stores feces.
6. **Rectum & Anus**: Feces storage and elimination.

---

### üß™ Accessory Organs

- **Liver**: Produces bile; processes nutrients and toxins.
- **Gallbladder**: Stores and concentrates bile.
- **Pancreas**: Produces digestive enzymes and bicarbonate.

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **GERD**: Acid reflux due to lower esophageal sphincter weakness.
- **Peptic Ulcers**: Erosion of stomach/duodenal lining.
- **Malabsorption Syndromes**: Celiac disease, lactose intolerance.

---

### üß† Key Takeaway

The GI tract is essential for digestion, absorption, and elimination ‚Äî with critical support from the liver, gallbladder, and pancreas.

topics.title: Brain & Meninges

topics.notes:
### üß† Brain & Meninges

The brain is the control center of the body, enclosed by **meninges** that provide protection.

---

### üß¨ Brain Divisions

- **Cerebrum**: Largest part, responsible for cognition, emotion, motor, and sensory processing
- **Cerebellum**: Coordination and balance
- **Brainstem**: Midbrain, pons, medulla ‚Äî autonomic and relay functions

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance

- **Meningitis**: Inflammation of meninges

Understanding the layers and structure of the brain and meninges is critical for managing neurological conditions.

The **orbit** contains the eyeball, muscles, nerves, and vessels.

topics.title: Glycolysis
topics.description: Main metabolic pathway for glucose breakdown.
topics.notes:
### ‚ö° Glycolysis: Fast Glucose Breakdown

**Glycolysis** is a key metabolic pathway that converts **glucose (6C)** into **2 pyruvate (3C)**, generating energy.

---

### üìç Location
- **Cytoplasm** of all cells (aerobic & anaerobic)

---

### üîë Key Points
- Net yield: **2 ATP**, **2 NADH** (per glucose)
- No oxygen required (anaerobic-capable)
- First step of cellular respiration

---

### üß¨ Rate-Limiting Enzyme
- **Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1)**
  - Activated by AMP, inhibited by ATP & citrate

---

### üß™ Important Steps
1. **Glucose ‚Üí G6P** (Hexokinase)
2. **F6P ‚Üí F1,6BP** (PFK-1) ‚Üê üî• commitment step
3. **PEP ‚Üí Pyruvate** (Pyruvate kinase)

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance
- **Pyruvate kinase deficiency** ‚Üí hemolytic anemia
- **Warburg effect** in cancer cells = high glycolysis even with oxygen

---

### üß† Key Takeaway
Glycolysis provides **quick ATP**, operates without oxygen, and feeds into multiple critical pathways (TCA, lactate, acetyl-CoA).

topics.title: TCA Cycle
topics.description: Central metabolic cycle that oxidizes acetyl-CoA into CO‚ÇÇ and energy.
topics.notes:
### üîÅ TCA Cycle (Krebs Cycle)

The **TCA cycle** oxidizes **acetyl-CoA** into **CO‚ÇÇ**, producing high-energy molecules.

---

### üìç Location
- **Mitochondrial matrix**

---

### üîë Key Products (Per Acetyl-CoA)
- **3 NADH**
- **1 FADH‚ÇÇ**
- **1 GTP (ATP)**
- **2 CO‚ÇÇ**

---

### ‚õΩ Entry Point
- Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate ‚Üí Citrate

### üß¨ Rate-Limiting Enzyme
- **Isocitrate dehydrogenase**

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance
- Inhibited by ATP, NADH, citrate
- **Anaplerotic reactions** replenish cycle intermediates

---

### üß† Key Takeaway
The TCA cycle is a **hub of metabolism**, feeding into the ETC and providing substrates for biosynthesis.

topics.title: Electron Transport Chain
topics.description: Final step of aerobic respiration producing ATP via oxidative phosphorylation.
topics.notes:
### ‚öôÔ∏è Electron Transport Chain (ETC)

The **ETC** uses electrons from NADH/FADH‚ÇÇ to generate **ATP** via proton pumping.

---

### üìç Location
- **Inner mitochondrial membrane**

---

### üß¨ Key Complexes
- **Complex I**: NADH ‚Üí CoQ
- **Complex II**: FADH‚ÇÇ ‚Üí CoQ
- **Complex III**: CoQ ‚Üí Cyt c
- **Complex IV**: Cyt c ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí H‚ÇÇO
- **ATP Synthase** (Complex V): Makes ATP using H‚Å∫ gradient

---

### ü©∫ Clinical Relevance
- Blocked by cyanide (Complex IV), rotenone (I), oligomycin (V)
- ETC defects = mitochondrial disease

---

### üß† Key Takeaway
ETC is the **main source of ATP**, coupling electron transfer to proton gradient & ATP production.

topics.notes:

Describes how **substrate concentration** affects enzyme activity.

### üß† Key Takeaway

topics.title: Amino Acid Metabolism

### üß† Key Takeaway

topics.title: Lipid Metabolism

### üßà Lipid Metabolism

Lipids provide long-term energy and membrane structure.

---

### üî• Key Pathways

topics.title: Nucleotide Metabolism

topics.notes:

Balanced nucleotide metabolism is vital for **genetic stability** and **cell division**.

topics.title: Introduction to Histology
topics.description: Overview of histology as the study of tissues, including microscope basics and tissue classification.
topics.notes:
### üß´ Introduction to Histology

Histology is the **microscopic study of tissues** and how they organize to form organs.

---

### üî¨ Microscopy Basics
- **Light Microscopy**: Most common for staining
- **Electron Microscopy (TEM/SEM)**: For ultrastructure

---

### üìå Tissue Processing Steps
1. Fixation (formalin)
2. Embedding (paraffin)
3. Sectioning (~5 ¬µm)
4. Staining (H&E most common)

---

### üß† Major Tissue Types
1. **Epithelial**
2. **Connective**
3. **Muscle**
4. **Nervous**

topics.title: Epithelium
topics.description: Classification and function of epithelial tissues.
topics.notes:
### üß± Epithelium

Epithelial tissues **line surfaces, protect organs**, and form **glands**.

---

### üìå Classification
- **By Layers**:
  - Simple (1 layer)
  - Stratified (>1 layer)
  - Pseudostratified (appears layered, isn't)
- **By Shape**:
  - Squamous (flat)
  - Cuboidal (cube)
  - Columnar (tall)

---

### üîç Key Locations
- Simple squamous: Alveoli, endothelium
- Simple cuboidal: Kidney tubules
- Pseudostratified: Respiratory tract
- Stratified squamous: Skin, esophagus

---

### üß† Key Takeaway
Epithelia are **polarized**, **avascular**, and rest on a **basement membrane**.

topics.title: Connective Tissue
topics.description: Overview of connective tissue types, components, and functions.
topics.notes:

Supports, binds, and protects tissues. Most **abundant and diverse** tissue type.

---

### üî¨ Components
- **Cells**: Fibroblasts, adipocytes, macrophages
- **Fibers**: Collagen (strength), Elastic (stretch), Reticular (framework)
- **Ground Substance**: Fills space, supports exchange

---

### üìå Types
- **Loose (Areolar)**: Under epithelium
- **Dense Regular**: Tendons, ligaments
- **Dense Irregular**: Dermis, capsules
- **Specialized**: Cartilage, Bone, Blood

---

### üß† Key Takeaway
CT connects and supports other tissues ‚Äî **structure and repair** are its core jobs.

topics.title: Muscle Tissue
topics.description: Structure and function of skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle tissues.
topics.notes:
### üí™ Muscle Tissue

Muscle tissue generates **movement**, **posture**, and **heat**.

---

---

- Skeletal: Attached to bone

---

### üß† Key Takeaway
Muscle types differ by **appearance**, **location**, and **control mechanism**.

topics.title: Poisoning and Overdose
